items.title: City Names 17 Schools Slated to Close
items.abstract: New York City education officials released the first round of names of schools to be shut down, with more names coming on Tuesday.
keywords: High School of Graphic Communication Arts

items.title: In a Crowded City, Storage Rooms With Amenities
items.abstract: A new self-storage facility, with customer-friendly extras, has opened on Manhattan’s West Side, but analysts said the city remains underserved.

items.title: ‘Making Room’ in the City
items.abstract: An exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York includes a full-size model of a micro-apartment.
keywords: Museum of the City of New York

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: India’s Capital City Celebrates ‘Design Week’
items.abstract: The best of Indian design, showcased in New Delhi.

items.title: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
items.abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: ‘Paradise City,’ by Elizabeth Day
items.abstract: A novel sets the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case in London.

items.title: Donald Trump Finds New City to Insult: Brussels
items.abstract: “It’s like living in a hellhole right now,” Donald J. Trump told the Fox Business Network anchor Maria Bartiromo.

items.title: Justin Peck Calmly Creates a Kingdom at City Ballet
items.abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which debuts on Tuesday, is the 10th ballet Mr. Peck has choreographed for the company he joined in 2007.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: An Indian City Bursting With Action
items.abstract: The present-day version of Chennai in South India dates back to only the 1600s, so a relatively youthful exuberance should not come as a surprise.

items.title: Who Are the Candidates for Public Advocate on Tuesday?
items.abstract: A whopping 17 people are running for New York City public advocate, with two debates scheduled ahead of the Feb. 26 special election.

items.title: Supreme Court Will Review New York City Gun Law
items.abstract: It is the court’s first Second Amendment case in nearly a decade and most likely means the court will start exploring and perhaps expanding gun rights.

items.title: In a Reversal, Kansas City’s Defense Plays Hero to Beat Broncos
items.abstract: Angling for the top seed in the A.F.C. with a win, Kansas City’s much maligned defense forced a fumble and returned it for a third-quarter touchdown.

items.title: Party for Hong Kong’s Elite Angers a City Under Covid Controls
items.abstract: Just as new restrictions were being imposed, top politicians were found to have attended a large gathering where at least one person had Covid.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: New York City sees ‘a glimmer of hope’ as virus cases level off, but they are still rising upstate.
items.abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said new coronavirus cases in New York City were beginning to plateau. The state will stop requiring counties to trace contacts, freeing public health resources for other needs.

items.title: Manchester City, Chelsea and Competing With Perfection
items.abstract: Pep Guardiola’s ideas and his teams have changed the way England views the game. The danger is that those changes affect perceptions of what qualifies as success.
